title: Week 2: What is language, and ethics in linguistic research
text:
During Week 2, we will talk about ethics in linguistic research, covering the following topics:

1. Outstanding questions2. Ethical Practices3. Institutions


What is language, and where is language?

What are the consequences of these answers when designing a linguistic survey?
How do our assumptions about ‚Äúwhere language lives‚Äù change how we ask questions?



What are ethical (or respectful) practices?

We will define what it means to be ethical in linguistic surveys (and any other kind of survey).
I will share real examples of ethical dilemmas and situations that I encountered in the past few years, and how to avoid such problems.



What are the institutional structures for research ethics in Taiwan?

We will focus on the Center for Taiwan Academic Research Ethics Education (in Chinese: Ëá∫ÁÅ£Â≠∏Ë°ìÂÄ´ÁêÜÊïôËÇ≤Ë≥áÊ∫ê‰∏≠ÂøÉ) provided by the Ministry of Education.
I will show you why you should care about these regulations, even as undergraduate and graduate students.

title: Introduction to Language Questionnaires
text:
üìã Course Description
This course introduces the fundamentals of online language questionnaires with an emphasis on hands-on practice. After discussing ethic issues in linguistic research, the course will be divided into three parts:

Fundamental concepts and practices in language questionnaires.
Set-up of a web-based questionnaire (using PCIbex).
Handling, analysis, and visualization of the results (using R).

By the end of the course, students are expected to acquire the basic knowledge of questionnaire design concepts and the capacity to design and run their own language questionnaire.
